explanation (cot): Constriction of afferent arteriole decreases the blood flow to the glomeruli, which can lead to a decrease in the glomerular filtration rate and an increase in intraglomerular pressure. This can ultimately lead to chronic kidney disease.

Axonal transport is the movement of materials along the length of a nerve fiber. There are two types of axonal transport: antegrade and retrograde. Antegrade transport moves materials from the cell body to the synapse, while retrograde transport moves materials from the synapse back to the cell body.

Low insulin to glucagon ratio is seen in glycogen breakdown, glycogen synthesis, and ketogenesis. In glycogen breakdown, glucagon stimulates the breakdown of glycogen to glucose, which can increase blood glucose levels. In glycogen synthesis, insulin promotes the synthesis of glycogen from glucose, which can decrease blood glucose levels. In ketogenesis, the liver produces ketones from fat breakdown, which can also increase blood glucose levels.
The concentration of tropicamide is 0.02.

Pregnant women with sore throats can be started immediately on oseltamivir without diagnostic testing under category B. People on long-term steroids can receive oseltamivir, but they are at risk of developing oseltamivir-resistant influenza. Category B concerns low-risk cases, and immediate testing is not required.
The septal branch of the superior labial artery is not a branch of the external carotid artery in Kiesselbach's plexus.

The ECG shows a P pulmonale, which is a positive deflection in the pulmonary component of the P wave. This can be caused by a number of factors, including left atrial enlargement, pulmonary hypertension, and pulmonary disease.

Oligaemic lung field and normal sized heart are consistent with Tetralogy of Fallot. The cyanosis is due to right-to-left shunt through the patent ductus arteriosus. The diagnosis is most likely Tetralogy of Fallot.

The correct answer is 'Before performing the ABG, syringe should be loaded with 0.3 cc of heparin' because heparin is used as an anticoagulant to prevent clotting of blood in the syringe during the procedure. The other options are not related to the procedure of ABG.

The respiratory rhythm generation center is located in the Pre-Botzinger complex, which is a group of neurons in the medulla oblongata that regulate breathing. The other options are not related to the respiratory rhythm generation center.

Gait apraxia is seen in thromboembolic episode involving the posterior choroidal artery (PCA). The PCA supplies blood to the basal ganglia, which is responsible for motor control and coordination. The other options are not related to the cause of gait apraxia.

The next step of management for a patient who pulls out the endotracheal tube is to assess the patient, give bag and mask ventilation, and look for spontaneous breathing. The patient may require reintubation if they are unable to breathe on their own.

The characteristic of venous blood flow of lower limb in duplex Doppler is biphasic, meaning it has two components: a systolic component (forward flow) and a diastolic component (backflow). The other options are not related to the characteristic of venous blood flow.
2,3-BPG binds to sites of hemoglobin and increases the affinity for oxygen. The other options are not related to the effect of 2,3-BPG on hemoglobin.

The highest concentration of oxygen is delivered through a venturi mask, which uses a jet of compressed air to entrain and mix with room air, providing a high concentration of oxygen. Refer to medical textbooks or online resources for more information

The risk of transmission of Hepatitis B from a mother who is Hbs Ag positive and anti Hbe Ag positive to her child is 50%. This is because the mother has chronic Hepatitis B infection and is shedding the virus in her blood, which can be transmitted to the child during childbirth or breastfeeding. Refer to medical textbooks or online resources for more information

The patient presented to the emergency department with an overdose of some drug, which has caused increased salivation and bronchial secretions. The patient's blood pressure is also low. These symptoms are consistent with an anticholinergic overdose. The appropriate treatment for this patient would be physostigmine, which is an antidote for anticholinergic poisoning. Refer to medical textbooks or online resources for more information

The appropriate test for comparing the data of newborns' weights based on whether their mothers received food supplements or not would be a t-test. A t-test is used to compare the means of two groups, in this case, the weights of newborns whose mothers received food supplements and those whose mothers did not receive food supplements. Refer to statistical textbooks or online resources for more information

Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is required for the activity of glycogen phosphorylase, which is an enzyme involved in glycogen metabolism. Refer to medical textbooks or online resources for more information

The only complete cartilage ring in the respiratory tree is the cricoid cartilage. The cricoid cartilage is a complete ring that surrounds the laryngeal inlet and forms the lower part of the larynx. Refer to medical textbooks or online resources for more information
